videoError.title: Videodemonstrationen sind in der mobilen App sichtbar
videoError.pathError: Video konnte nicht geladen werden von: {{path}}
videoError.instructions: Bitte stellen Sie sicher, dass MP4-Dateien im Verzeichnis public/Video/Blocks mit diesen Dateinamen platziert sind:

ageUke.name: Age Uke
ageUke.description: Eine Blocktechnik, die einen Angriff nach oben abwehrt und das Gesicht und den Oberkörper schützt.

gedanBarai.name: Gedan Barai
gedanBarai.description: Ein fegender Block, der Angriffe auf den Unterkörper abwehrt.

sotoUke.name: Soto Uke
sotoUke.description: Ein Block, der einen Angriff von innen nach außen abwehrt.

uchiUke.name: Uchi Uke
uchiUke.description: Ein Block, der einen Angriff von außen nach innen abwehrt.

shutoUke.name: Shuto Uke
shutoUke.description: Ein Block, der mit der Seite der Hand ausgeführt wird.

empiUke.name: Empi Uke
empiUke.description: Ein Block, der mit dem Ellbogen ausgeführt wird.

kosaUke.name: Kosa Uke
kosaUke.description: Ein Block, der mit gekreuzten Handgelenken ausgeführt wird.

jujiUke.name: Juji Uke
jujiUke.description: Ein Block, der mit gekreuzten Armen in X-Form ausgeführt wird.

haiwanUke.name: Haiwan Uke
haiwanUke.description: Ein Block, der mit der Rückseite des Unterarms ausgeführt wird.

practice.title: Praxis
practice.techniquesDesc: Lerne die grundlegenden Techniken des Goju Ryu

study.title: Lernbereich
study.description: Interaktive Lektionen und Quiz zum Vertiefen deines Wissens
study.quizDesc: Teste dein Wissen zu verschiedenen Themen.
study.flashcardDesc: Wiederhole Begriffe und Konzepte mit Lernkarten.

bunkai.title: [DE] Bunkai
bunkai.description: [DE] Application and analysis of kata techniques

gekisaiDaiIchi.title: [DE] Gekisai Dai Ichi Bunkai
gekisaiDaiIchi.description: [DE] Literally means 'attack and destroy 1'. This unusually aggressive name for karate reflects the era when Okinawa was a battlefield for Japanese-American war actions. The kata was developed in 1940 by the founder of Okinawa Goju-ryu Karate-do, Miyagi Chojun sensei. It consists of various combinations of simple basic techniques, which facilitate learning the later, more difficult classical koryu kata.

bunkai1.name: [DE] Jodan Age Uke + Jodan Oi Zuki
bunkai1.footwork: [DE] 45° diagonal step back to Heiko Sanchin Dachi + foot switch (in-out).
bunkai1.notes: [DE] Always maintain Zanchin. This applies to all bunkai!

bunkai2.name: [DE] Gedan Harai Uke
bunkai2.defense: [DE] Gedan Harai Uke (as strike and block simultaneously).
bunkai2.footwork: [DE] Sideways step outward into Shiko Dachi.
bunkai2.notes: [DE] When training with hard contact, do not attack the vital point [Hijitsume] but the forearm!

bunkai3.name: [DE] Chudan Yoko Uke + Mae Geri + Hiji Ate + Jodan Uraken Uchi
bunkai3.counterAttack: [DE] Gedan Mae Geri + Chudan Hiji Ate + Jodan Uraken Uchi.
bunkai3.footwork: [DE] Sayu Tenshin + after Mae Geri step forward into Zenkutsu Dachi.
bunkai3.vitalPoints: [DE] E.g. [Kinteki] (Mae Geri) + [Ganka] or [Suigetsu] (Hiji Ate) + [Jinchu] (Jodan Uraken Uchi).
bunkai3.notes: [DE] The low front kick is executed with the ball of the foot, the front of the ankle, or the shin depending on the distance. The attacker evades the Chudan Hiji Ate with a backward Suri Ashi.

bunkai4.name: [DE] Gedan Harai Uke + Chudan Gyaku Zuki
bunkai4.notes: [DE] Advanced students (from brown belt) must practice the block and counter-attack as one movement. The last two Bunkai Kumite must also be trained as one unit by advanced students.

bunkai5.name: [DE] Ashi Barai + Yoko Shuto Uchi + Hikite + Fumikomi Geri
bunkai5.counterAttack: [DE] Ashi Barai + Yoko Shuto Uchi + Fumikomi Geri.
bunkai5.vitalPoints: [DE] E.g. [Jinchu] or Adam's apple [Nodo Botoku] (Yoko Shuto Uchi) + neck (Fumikomi Geri).
bunkai5.notes: [DE] Quickly return the foot after Ashi Barai to prevent the opponent from attacking your leg. For the opponent's safety, the Yoko Shuto Uchi is not executed as a strike to a Kyusho, but more as a push to the chest and shoulder. The Fumikomi Geri can be executed with either leg, depending on how the opponent falls. However, in the Kata it is the same leg as the one used for the sweep. Advanced karateka can also make an irimi step and sweep the opponent from close range. In this advanced variation, the elbow is also locked on the chest.

bunkai6.name: [DE] Awase Zuki
bunkai6.defense: [DE] Nagashi Seiken Ura Uke (variant of Chudan Yoko Uke).
bunkai6.footwork: [DE] Sayu Tenshin + step into Zenkutsu Dachi.
bunkai6.notes: [DE] The attack must be intercepted early. The Awase Zuki must first be powerfully focused before continuing as a push. To do this, you must first relax inward and downward and let the breath come in. The Awase Zuki is a miniaturized, closed-hand version of the Tora Guchi.

gekisaiDaiNi.title: [DE] Gekisai Dai Ni Bunkai
gekisaiDaiNi.description: [DE] Literally means 'attack and destroy 2'. Like Gekisai Dai Ichi, developed by Miyagi Chojun sensei for the same reasons. The kata consists of various combinations of simple basic techniques, which facilitate learning the later, more difficult classical koryu kata.

bunkai1.name: [DE] Hiki Uke
bunkai1.vitalPoints: [DE] E.g. Adam's apple [Nodo Botoke] and/or carotid artery [Matsukaze].
bunkai1.notes: [DE] When slipping in (Suri Ashi), hook the front foot around the attacker's front foot and apply a leg lock, or place your front foot on the attacker's front foot. Lock the attacking arm between your upper arm and flank.

bunkai2.name: [DE] Nihon Hiki Uke
bunkai2.attack: [DE] Chudan Oi Zuki + Jodan Gyaku Zuki.
bunkai2.footwork: [DE] One step back or two Sayu Tenshin.
bunkai2.notes: [DE] With the hand/arm of the second attack, you lock up the other arm. Optionally apply pressure with the big toe on the forefoot [Kori].

bunkai3.name: [DE] Tora Guchi
bunkai3.footwork: [DE] Sayu Tenshin to Neko Ashi Dachi, then step out. After the push, pull back the rear foot.
bunkai3.vitalPoints: [DE] E.g. [Kinteki] and carotid artery/Adam's apple [Matsukaze]/[Nodo Botoke].
bunkai3.notes: [DE] Intercept attack early and execute with Muchimi.

saifa.title: [DE] Saifa Bunkai
saifa.description: [DE] Means something like 'destructive strikes'. 'Sai' means, as in Gekisai, 'destroy'. 'Fa' means, among other things, 'strike'. Typical for kata Saifa are the many striking techniques, such as uraken uchi, tettsui uchi, and haito uchi. Saifa is the first classical koryu kata.

bunkai1.name: [DE] Hazushi Waza + Otoshi Uke + Jodan Uraken Uchi
bunkai1.defense: [DE] 1. Hazushi Waza (release technique). 2. Shotei Otoshi Uke.
bunkai1.footwork: [DE] 45° step in and turn into Heiko Dachi, then step in or back to Shiko Dachi.
bunkai1.notes: [DE] When stepping in, press the knuckles of the grabbed hand/arm against the opponent's forearm to weaken their grip (maintain pressure from the start). When pulling free (Hazushi Waza), keep your arms close to your body. After the Otoshi Uke, grab the arm (don't grab immediately). The block can also be executed in Osae or Nagashi form.

bunkai2.name: [DE] Sukui Uke + Shotei Gedan Harai Uke + Hiza Ate + Mae Geri
bunkai2.defense: [DE] Sukui Uke + Shotei Gedan Harai Uke.
bunkai2.footwork: [DE] From Heiko Dachi back with Suri Ashi to Heiko Sanchin Dachi.
bunkai2.notes: [DE] With the Sukui Uke, the other hand is used as protection. The attacker must immediately retract the Mae Geri. When the attacker turns their torso sideways after retracting the Mae Geri, make the Mae Geri to the flank.

bunkai3.name: [DE] (Morote Hiki Uke +) Heiko Zuki
bunkai3.footwork: [DE] One foot back + forward Suri Ashi or Ayumi Ashi (depending on distance). In case of large, strong opponent: two Sayu Tenshin.
bunkai3.notes: [DE] The Morote Nukite Zuki and Morote Oshi are executed as much as possible in one movement.

bunkai4.name: [DE] (Morote) Gedan Furi Uchi
bunkai4.counterAttack: [DE] Morote Gedan Furi Uchi + Kubi Nage.
bunkai4.footwork: [DE] Kotai Ayumi Ashi possibly turn away when throwing.
bunkai4.notes: [DE] Grab at the ears or at the jaw and hair.

bunkai5.name: [DE] Tettsui Uchi + TsukamiHiki + Ura Zuki + Jodan Gyaku 'Zuki'
bunkai5.counterAttack: [DE] Tettsui Uchi + Tsukkamihiki + Ura Zuki + Jodan (Gyaku) Oshi.
bunkai5.footwork: [DE] Tai Sabaki, then step out for the Ura Zuki and possibly step through for the push (Ayumi Ashi).
bunkai5.vitalPoints: [DE] E.g. fontanel [Shomon] (Tettsui Uchi) + nose (Ura Zuki) + possibly Eye [Gansei] (Oshi).
bunkai5.notes: [DE] Keep the arm round and close to the body during the low block (don't 'scoop').

bunkai6.name: [DE] Haito Uchi
bunkai6.footwork: [DE] Sayu Tenshin to Neko Ashi Dachi.
bunkai6.vitalPoints: [DE] E.g. Floating rib/kidneys [Ushiro Denko] or neck [Keichu].
bunkai6.notes: [DE] In the Kata, the Haito Uchi is a Chudan technique.

bunkai7.name: [DE] Tora Guchi
bunkai7.footwork: [DE] Sayu Tenshin to Neko Ashi Dachi, then step out. After the push, pull back the rear foot.
bunkai7.vitalPoints: [DE] E.g. [Kinteki] and carotid artery/Adam's apple [Matsukaze]/[Nodo Botoke].
bunkai7.notes: [DE] Intercept attack early and execute with Muchimi.

seiyunchin.title: [DE] Seiyunchin Bunkai
seiyunchin.description: [DE] Literally means 'to unbalance in battle'. This kata is the only kaishu kata without kicking techniques and emphasizes the formation of strong, stable stances. The bunkai kumite (applications) consist of various wrestling and throwing techniques that are very suitable for close combat. Exam material for sankyu (third kyu, brown belt) and above.

bunkai1.name: [DE] Morote Gedan Harai Uke
bunkai1.counterAttack: [DE] Hiza Geri or Mae Geri (front or back leg).
bunkai1.footwork: [DE] First step forward, then diagonally back to Shiko Dachi.
bunkai1.notes: [DE] It is important to first weaken the opponent's grip (double upward thrust). The meaning of dropping into Shiko Dachi is to learn to use your weight as power in release techniques.

bunkai2.name: [DE] Sukui Uke + Hiki Uke + Hira Nukite Zuki
bunkai2.footwork: [DE] One foot back, then step out to Shiko Dachi.
bunkai2.notes: [DE] With Nukite Zuki, first make contact, then apply force.

bunkai3.name: [DE] Hojo Oshi
bunkai3.counterAttack: [DE] Chudan Nakadaka Ippon Ken Zuki + Morote Shotei Hojo Oshi
bunkai3.footwork: [DE] Turn into Heiko Sanchin Dachi + Suri Ashi forward during the push.

bunkai4.name: [DE] Chudan Hiji Ate
bunkai4.footwork: [DE] One foot back, then the other forward.

bunkai5.name: [DE] Hojo Uke + Gedan Harai Uchi
bunkai5.notes: [DE] From Shodan level, these bunkai and the next (with Gedan Barai) are performed as one continuous technique.

bunkai6.name: [DE] Hari Uke
bunkai6.defense: [DE] Kaishu Jodan Age Uke (+ grab) + Gedan Shotei Harai Uke (+ grab)
bunkai6.footwork: [DE] One foot back, then the other foot to the opponent's supporting leg and then Tai Sabaki. For lighter karateka, two times Sayu Tenshin.
bunkai6.notes: [DE] For safety, the throw is performed with a large turning movement. In a self-defense situation, with a not too heavy opponent, the throw is short and the head is...

bunkai7.name: [DE] Chudan Yoko Shotei Uke / Jodan Uchi Uke > Jodan Uraken Uchi
bunkai7.attack: [DE] Chudan Gyaku Zuki + Jodan Jun Zuki
bunkai7.defense: [DE] Otoshi Uke (+ grab) + Jodan Uchi Uke.
bunkai7.counterAttack: [DE] (optionally Ashi Barai with front leg +) Jodan Uraken Uchi
bunkai7.footwork: [DE] One foot back. Optionally slip in with Jodan Uraken Uchi.
bunkai7.notes: [DE] Only make the Ashi Barai if the distance allows.

bunkai8.name: [DE] (Doji Uke +) Age Zuki + Jodan Uraken Uchi + Gedan Harai Uke (Uchi)
bunkai8.counterAttack: [DE] Age Zuki + Jodan Uraken Uchi + Gedan Harai Uchi.
bunkai8.footwork: [DE] One foot back, then step out to Shiko Dachi.
bunkai8.vitalPoints: [DE] E.g. jaw [Mikazuki] (Age Zuki) + [Jinchu] (Jodan Uraken Uchi) + [Kinteki] (Gedan Harai Uchi).
bunkai8.notes: [DE] Advanced students should also practice this against Chudan Zuki + Gedan Zuki or Mae Geri (application of Doji Uke).

bunkai9.name: [DE] Hiji Age
bunkai9.defense: [DE] Hiji Age + Ushiro Hiji Ate (simultaneously) then turn out to Kamae.
bunkai9.footwork: [DE] After being grabbed, step forward to 'Neko Ashi Dachi'.
bunkai9.notes: [DE] If the grip is too strong, first attack a Kyusho. For example, with a backward headbutt, kick to the foot, strike to the groin, etc.

bunkai10.name: [DE] Otoshi Uke + Jodan Uraken Uchi
bunkai10.notes: [DE] The block and the strike follow each other smoothly.

bunkai11.name: [DE] Morote Kuri Uke
bunkai11.defense: [DE] Morote Kuri Uke as a release technique.
bunkai11.footwork: [DE] Step back and fall into Neko Ashi Dachi.
bunkai11.notes: [DE] As in the kata, it is important that the forearms come together well above the opponent's arms.

bunkai12.name: [DE] Chudan Oi Zuki > Chudan Yoko Uke + grab wrist > Gedan Harai Uke (Uchi)
bunkai12.defense: [DE] Chudan Yoko Uke + immediately continue to grab the wrist.
bunkai12.footwork: [DE] Sayu Tenshin, 30 degree turn + foot switch (back-in) to Shiko Dachi.
bunkai12.notes: [DE] When moving to Shiko Dachi, turn in such a way that you can hit the groin unimpeded.

shisochin.title: [DE] Shisochin Bunkai
shisochin.description: [DE] Literally means 'fight in 4 directions'. Another translation is '4 doors'. The word door is a symbolic word for the place where a potential opponent can attack, can 'enter'. The kata contains a typical attack combination, which is performed in four directions. Exam material for ikkyu (first kyu, brown belt) and above.

bunkai1.name: [DE] Chudan Nukite Zuki
bunkai1.vitalPoints: [DE] E.g. solar plexus [Suigetsu]) or carotid artery [Matsukaze].
bunkai1.notes: [DE] An attack to Suigetsu will only be realistic with a large strength difference and strong hands.

bunkai2.name: [DE] Morote Sukui Uke + 'Morote Gedan Harai Uke'
bunkai2.defense: [DE] Morete Sukui Uke + grab + 'Morete Gedan Harai Uke'.
bunkai2.counterAttack: [DE] Mae Geri or Hiza Geri with rear leg.
bunkai2.footwork: [DE] Step back to avoid the attack and to grab the opponent's thumbs or wrists.
bunkai2.notes: [DE] The same bunkai can also be performed if both wrists are grabbed.

bunkai3.name: [DE] Chudan Ura Kake Uke (Doji Uke) + Gyaku Te
bunkai3.footwork: [DE] Sayu Tenshin, then turn in with the outer leg and then stretch it to unbalance the opponent. Then turn to Shiko Dachi for Otoshi Hiji Ate.
bunkai3.notes: [DE] Advanced students should perform the block and Gyaku Te in one movement. The technique in question does not have a name of its own but is named after the application. Namely: Gyaku Te, which is a collective name for locks, grips, etc.

bunkai4.name: [DE] Hiji Age / Ushiro Hiji Ate
bunkai4.attack: [DE] Grab from behind, one arm trapped.
bunkai4.defense: [DE] Jodan Ushiro Zuki + Ushiro Hiji Ate.
bunkai4.notes: [DE] If the hold is too strong, it is better to attack a Kyusho first. For example, the point [Koin] (on the foot) with the heel or the testicles [Kinteki] with the hand.

bunkai5.name: [DE] Nagashi Shotei Gedan Harai Uke + Shotei Zuki
bunkai5.footwork: [DE] Step in and turn away in one movement.
bunkai5.notes: [DE] The upward effect in the movement helps uproot the opponent. In the case of an attack on the eyes, the opponent's hand is more difficult to see coming because it comes from below.

bunkai6.name: [DE] Hiki Uke + Mae Geri + Chudan Hiji Ate
bunkai6.counterAttack: [DE] Gedan Mae Geri + Chudan Hiji Ate + Nihon Nukite.
bunkai6.footwork: [DE] Sayu Tenshin. After Mae Geri move forward into Zenkutsu Dachi.
bunkai6.vitalPoints: [DE] E.g. [Kinteki] (Gedan Mae Geri) + [Ganka] (Chudan Hiji Ate) + Eyes [Gansei] (Nihon Nukite).

bunkai7.name: [DE] Otoshi Uke + Hiji Ate
bunkai7.notes: [DE] The attack must be intercepted early and pressed inward and (then) downward.

bunkai8.name: [DE] Morote Hiji Ate
bunkai8.footwork: [DE] One foot back for stability then step in.
bunkai8.vitalPoints: [DE] E.g. collarbone or chest (Otoshi Hiji Ate).
bunkai8.notes: [DE] Note: For the execution of Morote Hiji Age, the hands are raised and spread open.

bunkai9.name: [DE] Doji Uke
bunkai9.footwork: [DE] Sayu Tenshin to Neko Ashi Dachi, then forward Suri Ashi in Neko Ashi Dachi.

sanseru.title: [DE] Sanseru Bunkai
sanseru.description: [DE] Sanseru literally means '36 hands'. The name refers to Buddhist symbolism: 36 is the symbolic multiplication of 6 × 6. The first 6 stands for eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. The second 6 symbolizes color, voice, taste, smell, touch, and justice. This kata is exam material for nidan (second dan) and above. The bunkai focus on close-range defense, joint locks, and takedowns.

bunkai1.name: [DE] Chudan Yoko Uke > Chudan Gyaku Zuki
bunkai1.footwork: [DE] Right foot Sayu Tenshin with a turn to left Heiko Sanchin Dachi.

bunkai2.name: [DE] Kakate Uke > Hazushi Waza
bunkai2.attack: [DE] Kote Dori - left hand grabs right wrist
bunkai2.defense: [DE] Kake Uke + Hazushi Waza with the left hand on the wrist/forearm.
bunkai2.footwork: [DE] Step in with right to weaken the grip; step back with right to add force while performing Hazushi Waza.
bunkai2.notes: [DE] When performing Hazushi Waza, keep the arm close to the body, let the fingers go upward and then spread, then 'cut' with the knife hand.

bunkai3.name: [DE] Ashi Dori > Mae Geri > Kansetsu Geri
bunkai3.defense: [DE] Ashi Dori (right Shotei Uchi Gedan Harai Uke)
bunkai3.counterAttack: [DE] Chudan Ashi Dori + right Kin Geri + Kansetsu Geri Nage or Gedan Fumikomi.
bunkai3.footwork: [DE] Remain standing, turn the body away (Tai Sabaki in place).
bunkai3.notes: [DE] After the groin kick, turn the right hand and place the right thumb into the inner thigh muscle (quadriceps). After the kick, keep the knee inside the thigh and place the foot above the other knee. Use a lever motion for the takedown.

bunkai4.name: [DE] Mae Hiji Ate > Gedan Gyaku Zuki > Kansetsu Geri
bunkai4.attack: [DE] 1. Right Chudan Oi Zuki. 2. Left Gedan Gyaku Zuki.
bunkai4.defense: [DE] 1. Left Chudan Shotei Osae/Otoshi Uke. 2. Right Gedan Harai Uke.
bunkai4.counterAttack: [DE] 1. Right Chudan Hiji Ate + Left Gedan Gyaku Zuki + Right Kansetsu Geri.
bunkai4.footwork: [DE] 1. Foot switch (Uke + Hiji Ate). Kotai Suri Ashi (Uke) + left Sayu Tenshin (Kansetsu Geri).

bunkai5.name: [DE] Gedan Seiken Juji Uke
bunkai5.footwork: [DE] Right foot steps back into low Shiko Dachi.

bunkai6.name: [DE] Gedan Kaishu Juji Uke
bunkai6.footwork: [DE] Right foot steps back into low Shiko Dachi.

bunkai7.name: [DE] Mawashi Uke > Awase Zuki
bunkai7.attack: [DE] 1. Right Gedan Mae Geri. 2. Right Jodan Oi Zuki.
bunkai7.defense: [DE] 1. Gedan Shotei Harai Uke + grab. 2. Open hand Age Uke + grab (Gyaku Sukui Uke)
bunkai7.counterAttack: [DE] Awase Zuki Nage (combined punch and throw)
bunkai7.footwork: [DE] Step in with Sayu Tenshin turn (45 degrees)

bunkai8.name: [DE] Kami Kiri No Kamae
bunkai8.attack: [DE] Right Chudan Gyaku Zuki + Left Jodan Oi Zuki
bunkai8.defense: [DE] Left Chudan Yoko Ko Uke + Right Age Ko Uke
bunkai8.counterAttack: [DE] Double finger thrust + double palm strike + leg grab throw + downward palm strike.
bunkai8.footwork: [DE] First return to Heiko Sanchin (during Yoko Ko Uke), then step in to Shiko Dachi (Age Ko Uke)

theory.title: [DE] Kata Theorie
theory.description: [DE] Die Prinzipien und Praxis der Kata verstehen

sanchin.description: Das grundlegendste Kata im Goju Ryu. Es konzentriert sich auf richtige Atmung, Stand und Spannung im ganzen Körper. Die 'drei Kämpfe' beziehen sich auf Geist, Körper und Seele.
sanchin.history: Bedeutet wörtlich 'drei Kämpfe'. Es bezieht sich nicht auf einen tatsächlichen Kampf, sondern auf den inneren Kampf, Körper, Geist und Seele durch Willenskraft zu stärken. Das Kata besteht aus langsam ausgeführten Techniken mit kontinuierlicher Muskelspannung und tiefer Bauchatmung. Das moderne Sanchin ist eine von Miyagi Chojun Sensei (Begründer, 1888-1953) entwickelte Variante des Originals von Higaonna Kanryo Sensei. Die Atmung in der Originalversion war explosiver, und der Körper drehte sich zweimal um 180 Grad. Fortgeschrittene Schüler können während der Ausführung von Sanchin auf korrekte Muskelspannung getestet werden. Diese Prüfung wird Shime genannt. Prüfungsstoff für Gokyu (fünfter Kyu, grüner Gürtel) und höher.
sanchin.culturalSignificance: Sanchin gilt als die Essenz des Goju Ryu Karate und verkörpert die Prinzipien von Atmung, Stand und Fokus, die für den Stil zentral sind.

tensho.description: Bedeutet wörtlich 'drehende Handflächen'. Dieses Kata wurde von Miyagi Chojun Sensei als Gegenstück zu Sanchin entwickelt. Wie Sanchin wird es mit tiefer Atmung und allgemeiner Muskelspannung ausgeführt, aber sein Charakter ist ganz anders. Während Sanchin geschlossen, eckig und hart (go) ist, ist Tensho offen, anmutig und weich (ju), mit vielen kreisförmigen Hand- und Handgelenktechniken. Prüfungsstoff für Sandan (dritter Dan) und höher.
tensho.history: Von Chojun Miyagi als Gegenstück zu Sanchin entwickelt, repräsentiert Tensho den weichen, kreisförmigen Aspekt des Goju Ryu.
tensho.culturalSignificance: Tensho demonstriert das 'ju' (weiche) Element des Goju Ryu und ergänzt das 'go' (harte) von Sanchin.

history.title: Geschichte
history.origins-desc: Goju-Ryu Karate wurde Anfang des 20. Jahrhunderts von Chojun Miyagi in Okinawa, Japan, entwickelt. Der Name 'Goju' stammt vom Prinzip 'hart-weich' aus den traditionellen chinesischen Kampfkünsten und spiegelt die doppelte Natur des Systems wider – die Kombination harter Schlagtechniken mit weicheren, kreisförmigen Bewegungen für Angriff und Verteidigung.
history.development-desc: Die Entwicklung und Verbreitung von Goju Ryu in der ganzen Welt
history.lineage-desc: Die wichtigsten Lehrer und ihre Beiträge zum Stil

subsections.early-history-desc: Die Wurzeln des Goju Ryu reichen zurück bis zu den chinesischen Kampfkünsten und ihrer Integration in die okinawanische Kultur.
subsections.miyagi-era-desc: Chojun Miyagi's Entwicklung und Systematisierung des Goju Ryu Stils in den 1920er und 1930er Jahren.
subsections.post-war-desc: Die Verbreitung und Entwicklung des Goju Ryu nach dem Zweiten Weltkrieg.
subsections.modern-era-desc: Die aktuelle Entwicklung und weltweite Verbreitung des Goju Ryu.
